results.title: Co for kids
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Pierre Moretti, Gaston Sarault, Joseph Koenig, Dorothy Courtois and Co Hoedeman
results.brief_description: Three works from multi-award winning Canadian director/animator Co Hoedeman. All are silent apart from the musical effects. 1.”Tchou tchou” (1971, 14 mins): A children’s fantasy where painted building blocks represent a make believe city and the two children who play in it until an angry dragon appears on the scene. Themes of play, friendship, threat, fear, attack, defence, failure, inventive solutions, outwitting and success are supported by evocative music and sound effects to create a lively and optimistic “narrative”. 2.”The Sand Castle”, (1977, 13 mins): Set in an horizonless sand landscape, a sandman sculpts mythic like creatures from sand. Under his direction they build a wonderful sandcastle. Celebrating its completion they are interrupted by an uninvited, naughty guest. The wind blows strongly and each scrambles for shelter in the fragile sandcastle which becomes enveloped by sand, its outlines crumbling, leaving us where we began in the sand landscape. Interpretations are left to the mind of the viewer. (Awards: Winner of 22, including an Academy Award and a Melbourne International Film Festival Award) 3.”Matrioska”, (1970, 4.5 mins): A set of Russian Babushka dolls are used as a group of dancers who separate, merge, separate in a series of arrangement themes (eg. smallest to largest, youngest to oldest) to create a choreography. Minute differences of painted expressions, supported by action and music give character to each of the dolls.

results.title: Co-ordinated housing
results.creator_credit: Melbourne Photographic Service and A V Jennings Construction Company
results.brief_description: Illustrates the work done by the Jennings enterprise in pre-war years, and then on an increased scale during the period of post-war planning and development. Shows how raw materials such as timber, plaster, and roofing tiles were produced for the Heidelberg Housing Commission project, and how the production organisation built up in this way has made possible large housing projects throughout Victoria and also interstate.

results.title: Co-ops at work in Solomon Islands
results.creator_credit: Don Murray, Film Australia and Graham Chase
results.brief_description: Describes the various co-operatives in the Solomon Islands. These are an important part of economic life and assist villagers in the production and distribution of timber, foodstuffs, copra and exports which are regulated by the Central Co-op Association in the capital Honiara.

results.title: Co-operative research in industry
results.brief_description: The film shows how small industrial firms in Britain band together to form Research Associations, thus enabling scientific research to be undertaken to help industry to produce more and better goods. The film illustrates the working of this system by examples of practical assistance of research results in the tanning, electrical, motor, laundry and printing industries.

results.title: Co-operative learning: from 'me' to 'we'
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education and Rob McCubbin
results.brief_description: Presents a classroom view of cooperative learning highlighting the key aspects of successful implementation. It is based on the experiences of four teachers showing cooperative learning at different stages of use in their classrooms.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Ministry of Education and Rob McCubbin

results.title: Co-operative farming in East Germany
results.brief_description: Describes co-operative farming in East Germany, illustrates patterns of family and village life and provides economic and social insights into communal living. Includes scenes of potato harvesting, dairy farming and the activities of the Communist Party organisation - the Free German Youth.
results.description: Describes co-operative farming in East Germany, illustrates patterns of family and village life and provides economic and social insights into communal living. results.title: Co-operative behaviour (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera, Phil Content and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Co-operative behaviour enables groups of people to achieve a common goal. Firstly, a common goal must be decided on, and then behaviour co-ordinated between individuals to achieve this goal. Looks at co-operative behaviour in the classroom, and warns against confusing conformity and obedience with co-operation.

results.title: Co-operation, competition, conflict
results.brief_description: Based on the text book “Sociology” by Green, this film discusses how three fundamental social processes - competition, conflict and co-operation - operate to make society function.

results.title: Co-op housing: the best move we ever made
results.creator_credit: Kathleen Shannon, Laura Sky and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
The film explores the dimensions of the housing crisis in Canada, the definition of cooperative housing, and its possibilities as described by some of the people who are living in such dwellings today. Here, housing is owned and operated by people as users, not as investors. The film emphasizes an alternative in housing: security of tenure and mutual aid as the owner-families have come to value them.

results.title: Co-op housing: getting it together
results.creator_credit: Kathleen Shannon, Laura Sky and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
People, housing, funds and expertise: getting them together isn’t easy, but it can be done. The film deals with the planning and procedures involved in setting up a co-op, whether that means building one, or buying and rehabilitating existing housing. People living in different kinds of co-ops talk about them, and how they function.
